titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Charles and Joy Sheffey Papers
titlestmt.author: Martha Lund Smalley

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:27

did.unittitle: Charles and Joy Sheffey Papers
did.abstract: Charles and Joy Sheffey were American Methodist medical missionaries who served in Wembo Nyama, Belgian Congo (now Democratic Republic of the Congo) between 1922 and 1944. Letters, journals, and writings of Charles and Joy Sheffey document their medical work and record their reactions to the culture and environment they encountered in Africa.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection is open to qualified researchers

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Charles and Joy Sheffey Papers (RG 219), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library

chronitem.event: Charles Phillips Mahood Sheffey born in Lynchburg, VA, son of Edward Fleming Sheffey and Mattie Mahood Sheffey
Mae Joy Burch (Sheffey) born in Danville, VA, daughter of Nannie Towsey Burch and Rev. William G. Burch, a Methodist minister in the Virginia Conference
CPMS attended Randolph Macon College, receiving A.B. and M.A. degrees

CPMS graduated from School of Medicine of Johns Hopkins University in Baltimore, followed by additional training at New York Postgraduate Medical School ; he also served as an intern at Norfolk Protestant Hospital
CPMS served as medical missionary in Wembo Nyama, Belgian Congo (now Democratic Republic of the Congo) under the Methodist Board of Missions
JBS attended Longwood College and Lynchburg College, continuing her nursing training in Richmond, VA and Philadelphia, PA
CPMS and JBS married while CPMS was on extended stay in U.S. due to illness of his father
CPMS and JBS sailed for Africa, spending some months at École de Medécine Tropicale in Belgium en route; arrived in Congo in July
CPMS and JBS ran a medical training center in Wembo Nyama and provided surgical services to a region that spanned a 500-mile radius.
Daughter Grace born; she later attended the Central School for missionary children in Lubondai
Sheffey family returned to Lynchburg, VA where CPMS practiced medicine until his retirement in1969
CPMS received honorary LL.D. degree from Randolph Macon College

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters, journals, and writings of Charles and Joy Sheffey document their medical work and record their reactions to the culture and environment they encountered in Africa. Circular letters and writings provide substantive documentation of their life and work in the Belgian Congo between 1922 and 1944. Letters to and from their children Grace and Nancy provide detail about the life of missionary children in Africa. Of particular note are the records that Charles Sheffey kept to describe operations performed at the Wembo Nyama hospital and surrounding area. Collected material includes documentation of the Methodist Mission, school books in African languages used in its schools. Photographs document the Sheffey family and their mission in Wembo Nyama
The collection contains a notable number of diverse artifacts. These include African musical instruments, a "witch doctor's magic gourd", jewelry, metal implements, and textiles.

did.unittitle: Correspondence
Family correspondence
Charles to Joy, prior to their marriage
Charles to/from Joy, primarily prior to their marriage
Charles and Joy from their parents, primarily prior to their marriage
Charles and Joy from their parents
Charles and Joy to/from family members including excerpts of letters from Joy describing native customs, lions, locust.

Charles and Joy to/from family members, including excerpts of letters from Joy describing locusts, incident with leopard, medical work and her letter describing the Mission's historical pageant (1939)
Charles and Joy to their daughter Grace, written from Wembo Nyama while Grace was away at Central School in Lubondai

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Letters contain descriptions of everyday life at the Mission

did.unittitle: Nancy Sheffey to her sister Grace, written from Wembo Nyama while Grace was at Central School in Lubonda

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Interesting child's perspective on life at the Mission

did.unittitle: Grace Sheffey Webb to/from her aunt Grace
General correspondence
Published and mimeographed letters by Charles Sheffey describing his work in Africa
Primarily typescript letters from CPMS to churches describing his work
To/from others, including letter from President Franklin Roosevelt thanking JBS for Belgian Congo stamps, and circular letters of JBS
To/from others, including circular letters of JBS describing their work
To/from others, including re. book re. Sheffey family history
Letters of others, including excerpts from letters of Paul Alexander from Belgian Congo (1961)
Writings
By Charles Sheffey
Poems #4-91

Articles and essays, including "Surgery by Lamplight in the Congo", "Early Work among the Lepers of the Belgian Congo", "Death and Funeral Rites Among a Primitive People", "Two Hundred Miles Across Africa on a Bicycle", "African Youth and a Christian World", reports on medical work
By Joy Burch Sheffey
Essays, stories, newsletters, including series of "Tom Tom Notes", "Twenty-five Years of History Pass in Review", "Black Reflects Lights", others

Essays and stories, including "Ekanda, One of God's Black Children", "Great African Chief Reaches Journey's End", "On to Africa; a brief study of the Belgian Congo... for use in Sunday Schools and Public Schools"

Essays and stories, including "What the Native African Eats", "Again to the Heart of Africa", "African Womanhood", "A Leopard in a Rabbit Trap?", "Spreading the Gospel Among the Bush-people", "Congo Doctor"
By Grace Burch Sheffey
Compositions, including "My Favorite Vacation Spot", "Sandcastles", "Irish Superstitions", etc.
By others
Including poem "The Missionary Call" by Joy's mother Nannie Towsey Burch, essays by Lilian Mahood, "My Trip Home: Belgian Congo - USA 1946" by Serena Kelly
Notes and Diaries
Three notebooks with handwritten notes by CPMS recording operations he performed
Miscellaneous notes by CPMS and JBS
"Line a Day" diary of CPMS
"My Travels" notebook and small diary
Bound journal of CPMS
Biographical Documentation
Biographical sketches of CPMS and JBS
Student Volunteer Movement applications (Charles Phillips Mahood Sheffey)
"Wedding Memories" volume
Newspaper clippings about CPMS
Health information and miscellaneous biographical documentation about families
Information about grandfather of CPMS, Rev. Robert Sayers Sheffey, including book Brother Sheffey a Christian Who Knew the Power of Prayer by Willard Sanders Barbery
Information about father of CPMS, Edward F. Sheffey
Miscellaneous family biographical information
Genealogical documentation re. Sheffey and Mahood families
Collected Material
Related to Methodist mission in Congo medical work
Related to Methodist mission in Congo conference
Handmade Bible story booklet in African language
Related to Central School for Missionaries' children, Lubondai
Issues of "Jungle Log" published by the students of Central School for Missionaries' Children, Lubondai
African language writings
Maps of Congo; book Belgian Congo at War
Miscellaneous programs, cards, clippings
African language school books, Bible lessons, catechism, primarily published by the Methodist Episcopal Church Mission, Wembo Nyama
Pamphlets from "Little Books for Africa" series, published in London: "The Leopard and the Goat", "Tombo Temba" "Hausa Tales", "The Blood Brother"
Photographs
CPMS, JBS and daughters (See also Box Ov1 for framed portraits of CPMS)
Members of extended Sheffey family
Wembo Nyama mission and en route
Artifacts
Textiles: ten woven mats
Textiles: book bags, placemats, napkin, trivets
Textiles: woven mats
Metal: 12 inch knife, 1 copper hatchet, Y-shaped hairpin; letter opener; copper cross; metal anklet
3 hand made cloth dolls, 3 strands of red and white beads; 1 strand of witch doctor's beads with leopard tooth; headband for mourning; native comb; fan; ceremonial rattle; baby rattle
Wooden stool; feathered witch doctor's hat
Underwood typewriter
Woven carrier, grass skirt, tortoise shell; "witch doctor's magic gourd"; thumb piano
Large woven basket; Musical instrument made from snakeskin and ivory
Wooden messenger drum with drum sticks and metal staff
